coatOfArms.description: Coat of arms of Spanish Sahara

historicalContext.ifniWarAndAftermath: During the Ifni War, Ifni and the Sahara became separate provinces.
historicalContext.decolonizationPressure: Spain relinquished its Saharan possession following Moroccan demands and international pressure.

spanishPeriod.initialClaim: At the Berlin Conference, Spain declared a protectorate from Cape Blanc to Cape Bojador.
spanishPeriod.resistance: Spanish forces were challenged by stiff resistance from indigenous Sahrawi tribes.
spanishPeriod.treatyOfIdjil: In 1886, Spain signed the Treaty of Idjil with the Emirate of Adrar.

modernHistory.moroccanClaims: After gaining independence in 1956, Morocco laid claim to Spanish Sahara.
modernHistory.ifniWar: The Moroccan Army of Liberation nearly occupied Ifni in 1957.
modernHistory.polisarioFront: In 1973, the Polisario Front was formed, challenging Spanish rule.

presentStatus.UNStatus: Western Sahara is listed by the United Nations as a non-decolonized territory.
presentStatus.population: Moroccan settlers currently make up more than two thirds of the inhabitants.
presentStatus.legalStatus: Under international law, Western Sahara is not a legal part of Morocco.
